image.alt_text: Photo by Nicole Summers in Turtle Island with @warpartymovement. May be an image of 1 person, railroad and text that says 'WAR W WARPARTY 1 PARTY MOVEM MOVEMENT EMENT 人'.
image.caption:
Where is the media coverage?
Where are the FBI searches?
Where are the cameras?
Why aren't the faces of the countless murdered and missing indigenous women and girls plastered all over social media? 
Where are the thousands of cries for justice?
Why is it up to the families and relatives to find their missing loved ones? 
We must do better to bring these sacred women and girls home. 
NO MORE STOLEN SISTERS!!
#mmiw #warpartymovement #murderedandmissingindigenouswomen 
#mmiwg2s #mmiwawareness #mmiwg 
#nomorestolensisters

image.alt_text: Photo by Lizzie on August 28, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'Ruchika T @rtulshyan say this in my classes: The problem isn't men, it's patriarchy. The problem isn't white people, it's white supremacy. The problem isn't straight people, it's homophobia. Recognize systems of oppression before letting individual defensiveness paralyze you from dismantling them. LATINX PARENTING'.
image.caption:
Edit: like it or not, this is facts. Everyone should know this. Everyone should say this. Everyone.

Feelin this today. It’s sometimes hard to keep in mind that people who we may feel opposed to are actually also being oppressed by these same systems too. It HURTS to stretch your perspective, but if you put the effort in, you can build solidarity and the movement. Reposted from @latinxparenting
Reposted from @lakotalaw

image.alt_text: Photo by Marissa Duran in Dulce, New Mexico with @taniateyacapan. May be art.
image.caption:
My original painting "No More Stolen Sisters" has sold at the State Fair and it won the Audience Favorite Award of the whole show! I'm so grateful. It is very important to bring awareness to this issue and I'm thankful I was able to share it with the community. Thank you to the collector who purchased this piece. And thank you to everyone who voted for it.❤ 
#nomorestolensisters#mmiw#originalart#artbymarissaduran#strongreslientindigenous#arte

image.alt_text: Photo by @sassysouthernballetmama on August 10, 2021. May be an image of outdoors.
image.caption:
I have shared this stunning photo before, with permission, and share again today because I could not have a folk dance day without bringing forth the only true, Indigenous and Rooted in the land and people, North American dance. If you have never experienced Indigenous Dance - and this, my soul’s favorite, the Jingle Dance - I urge you to seek these forms of dance out. It’s impossible to live here on this land that is not ours, without understanding the lifeblood that is the Dance that springs from the land. And, if you are not already following @tapahe, please do. ❤️ Repost from @tapahe
•
Art Heals: The Jingle Dress Project
What do you see? I see, resilience, strength, and grace. They were born innocent and loving––unknowing the color of their skin and being women would influence their future.
Today is the National Day of Awareness of Missing & Murdered Indigenous Women (MMIW). On this day, and every day, we are the voice for the voiceless, remembering our sisters, aunts, mothers and grandmothers who are still missing.
1 IN 3 INDIGENOUS WOMEN HAVE BEEN SEXUALLY ASSAULTED…AND 2 OF 3 WILL EXPERIENCE VIOLENCE IN THEIR LIFETIME…Native American women are murdered 10x the national average rate––more than any other race.)
Our jingle dress photo project originated from a dream I had during the COVID pandemic. The images intend to reunite the land with the healing power of the jingle dress dance in order to help heal the people and protect the sacred.
-------------------
This image was taken at the Grand Teton National Park, Wyoming, native land of the Shoshone-Bannock, Gros Ventre and Nez Perce people. To learn about or support our project see my profile link. Scarves are available for sale with every scarf purchase we are providing a FREE MMIW pin.
#MMIW #MMIWG2S #MMIR #WhyWeWearRed #NoMoreStolenSisters #jingledress #jingledressproject #nativeamerican #nativeart #grandtetonnationalpark #wyoming snow
@reddawnfoster

image.alt_text: Photo shared by Marisa LaRen on October 11, 2021 tagging @jeremiah_blackbeard, and @warpartymovement. May be an image of one or more people.
image.caption:
It’s Indigenous People’s Day and the fact it’s not a national holiday is disheartening to say the least.

Today is to celebrate the people who first called this land home. 
To recognize their pain and hardships that still go on till this day.

It’s surprising how many people know very little about natives and what they go through.

I hope you take some time to educate yourself, not just today but always.

@warpartymovement 
@jeremiah_blackbeard

image.alt_text: Photo by SheNative on October 04, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'II Today is national Day of Action for mMIWG2S . NO MORE STOLEN SISTERS'.
image.caption:
Statistics: MMIWG⁠
⁠
As of 2016 there are more than 5,712 known incidents of missing or murdered Indigenous women.⁠
⁠
Indigenous women & girls are TWLVE TIMES more likely to be murdered or go missing.⁠
⁠
On some reservations, Indigenous women and girls are murdered at TEN TIMES the rate of Canada's national average.⁠
⁠
As of 2012, there are 1,181 ongoing investigations.⁠
⁠
3% of Canada's female population are Indigenous. However, they make up 10% of all female homicides in Canada.⁠
⁠
As of March 2010, 59% of missing women and girls in Saskatchewan are Indigenous.⁠
⁠
55 of cases involve women under the age of 31. 17% of cases involve girls under the age of 18.⁠
⁠
88% of missing Indigenous women are mothers. 440+ children have been impacted.⁠
⁠
28% of all MMIWG2S cases in Canada occur in British Columbia⁠
⁠
Documented cases appear to be over 4,000 while under-reporting of violence against Indigenous women and girls lack of an effective database.⁠
⁠
#notinvisible #nomorestolensisters #mmiwg2s #indigenousrights #supportindigenous #mmiw #mmiwg #missingandmurderedindigenouswomen #stolensisters #stolenland #landback #nationaldayofaction #1312 #canada #kkkanada #mmiwg2sawareness⁠
⁠
⁠

image.caption:
This is a friendly service announcement. 

While I deeply enjoy celebrating Halloween  my focus still remains on decolonizing, cleansing myself of toxic systemic racism, & being a dutiful ally. Still learning, still aching and still so devastated. 

If there is anyone out there that doesn't have income and still wants to put in work DM me and I can tell you some ways to volunteer. 

Don't know who created this post 😪

#landback #stopline3 #decolonize #mmiw #nomorestolensisters #stophate #fuckracism #blacklivesdomatter #stopcallingthepolice #translivesmatter #loveislove #stopasianhate

image.alt_text: Photo by Rocky C Karlage - Filmmaker on August 17, 2021.
image.caption:
Repost @intothewolvesdenthemovie - There are four Native American Indian Spirituality Laws that say nothing happens for no reason in life. When you do understand this, 
it's very easy to handle and you confidently look at what's happening, thankful for what was there and happy for what's going to happen.

The 1st law says:
′′ The person you meet is the right one ′′
That is, no one comes into our lives by accident, all the people around us who interact with us, stand for something, either to educate us or to help us in our situation.

The 2nd law says:
′′ What happens is the only thing that can happen ′′
Nothing but absolutely nothing of what happens to us could have been different. Not even the most insignificant detail. There just isn't ′′ If I had done it differently... It would have been different..." No, what happens is the only thing that can happen and needs to happen, so we can learn our lessons to get ahead. Everything, yes, every situation that happens to us in life is absolutely perfect, even when our spirit resists our ego and doesn't want to accept it.

The 3rd law says:
′′ Every moment when something starts is the right time ′′
Everything starts at the right time, not sooner or later. When we are ready for something new in our life, it's already there to begin with.

The 4th law says:
′′ What's over is over ′′
It's that simple. When something ends in our life, it serves our development. That's why it's better to let go and move forward, bestowed on the experiences that have now been gained.

I don't think it's a coincidence that you're reading this here. If this text meets you today, it's because you meet the conditions and understand that no rain drop anywhere in the world accidentally falls 
in the wrong place.
Let it go well...
Love with your whole being...
Being happy without end...
Every day is a happy, happy day. 
❤️ 
I Am. 
You Are.
We Are.
Oneness.
#nativeamerican #nativeamericanwisdom #nativeculture #mmiwg #heal #itstopsnow #betheirvoice #justiceforall 
#intothewolvesden #likeforlikes #insta #film #supportindiefilm #actors #director #music #whywewerered #nativeart #artist 
#lakota #Ojibwa #savannasact #nomorestolensisters

image.alt_text: Photo by Decolonial Clothing on August 11, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'LAND BACK IS ABOUT RELATIONSHIP. COLONIZATION IS ABOUT POWER.'.
image.caption:
Land Back is about returning to relationship. 

Colonialism is about profit and power. 

Every aspect of the colonial system of “Canada” is about access to land in order to generate wealth and power. To achieve this, they needed to separate us from this relationship by forced removal from our traditional lands and limiting our access to cultural land practices that are built on reciprocity rather than resource extraction. 

They even went so far as to destroy the thriving ecosystems of the land in an attempt to drive starvation of traditional resources (such as Buffalo massacres), in order to enact genocide and land theft. 

Further colonial oppression was established by introducing patriarchal governance (Indian Act Chiefs), targeting women and children through violence and breaking family units and breaking traditional knowledge inheritance through use of the Residential School System. 

Continuing to this day the colonial system makes it illegal for us to fight for stolen land. 

And they make it nearly impossible to fight for our babies that are STILL stolen from us by the government! 

All these things are connected as pieces of a systematic attack on our Indigenous ways of being in relationship with the Land, our mother. 

For these reasons and many more, we say LAND BACK. 

🌿

Want to learn more about the connection to Land? Comment 🦅 below: 

SHOP our LAND BACK collection- link in bio.

video.caption:
Edit: This has gotten a lot of likes so I want to stress that this is not me or my video. This is from @modern_warrior__ and I reposted it because I'm disgusted by what's happening in the state I live in.

Reposted from @lakotalaw @modern_warrior__ uses his platform to amplify the #MMIW of Line 3. When we fight to protect water, we are also fighting to keep Native Women, girls, & two-spirits safe.

#StopLine3 #NoPipelines
